title: Can riot stop being so insistent on adcs being the only late game class?
body: Right now, adcs get as much powerspike as mages and bruisers from 1st and 2nd item, yet they scale way harder than mages and bruisers with full build. Please bring back late game bruisers, if the adc gets to outscale my durability with his damage, than I should outscale his lifesteal with my damage.

{{item:3812}} for example makes sense on a squishy ADC. It doesn't reduce damage at all, just delays it and offers a "buy-back" opportunity to not die.
{{item:3046}} on the other hand, makes no sense to me. It's targeted at ADC's, who's defense is supposed to come from kiting, Life-steal, and teamwork. But Riot is giving them direct damage reduction (which is stronger than resists).

Similarly:
{{item:3504}} Gives squishy supports the ability to make *another* person more durable. But not themselves.
{{item:3109}} meanwhile makes tanks suffer *increased* damage to *reduce* the damage on another person. ***passively***
{{item:3190}} follows through with sensibility though. Makes the user *slightly* more durable, while giving *everyone* (including the user) an "oh shit" button.

{{item:3194}} reduction to repeat ability magic damage (because there are apparently no AD casters).
{{item:3082}} reduces AS
{{item:3143}} reduces crit
{{item:3047}} reduces AA's
While it seems like tanks should be the ones to enjoy broad options (my opinion); they're the ones forced to specialize. (>_>)

Mages have {{item:3157}} {{item:3048}} and health. Very little resists.
The thinking used to be that health soft-counters everything. While AD was more reliable. So AP got health and AD got resists. Tanks got damage supplements (Sunfire, Thornmail, etc.)
Now AD and AP have about equal access to health.

You all are wrong about the armor calculations.  Doesn't change the fact that his point is true though about how armor scales, every point is as equally valuable as the last.  The question is if it may be more worth it to get more HP after a point, which is a different matter.


Armor scales like this.

Every point of armor/mr grants you +1% effective HP vs that damage type.

At 100 armor, you are having your effective HP pool doubled vs physical damage.  At 200 armor, you had it tripled.


Lets use a fairly easy example.

You have exactly 2000 HP.  You have 100 armor.   This is worth 4000 HP vs physical damage.

You can buy a Warmog, or a Frozen Heart.

Warmog gives you 2800 HP, and still 100 armor.  This is 5600 HP vs physical.
Frozen Heart gives you 2000 HP, and 190 armor.  This is 5800 HP vs physical damage.


Now lets change the story up a bit.  You have 3000 HP, and 200 armor.  This is 9000 HP vs physical.

Warmog brings you to 3800 HP, and 200 armor.  11400 hp vs physical.
Frozen Heart gets you to 3000 hp and 290 armor.   11700 hp vs physical.



Armor has still had a greater impact on your durability vs physical than HP would have.  The main issue is you are rarely taking pure one damage type.    Pretty much the moment you start taking any other type of damage instead of just physical, HP's effective value on your durability is greater than armor.   Although more HP leaves you as a bigger health battery for LS users, so it isn't a clear cut tradeoff all the time.


Now, lets pretend you are Rammus, and are vs a pure physical team comp.   You build up to 500 armor while W is on, although you only have 2500 HP.  What will bulk you up the most?  500 more HP, or 100 more armor?

3000x6=18000 is the HP case.   2500x7=17500 is the armor.      You gained more HP from a much lower gold value of HP than armor just because you already had such a big armor "multiplier."

Agreed, I think defining an entire class of champions as carries has not had the best consequences, as carry champions outside of the class struggle to scale as hard, whereas "early game" marksmen all tend to still scale really well, and only scale poorly relative to other marksmen. There is nothing about the fantasy of playing a ranged attacker that is more inherently carry-like than that of playing a magic user or unstoppable warrior, and in practice marksmen are only the game's designated carries because DotA lacked ability scaling and features mostly autoattack-reliant carries. Nowadays, though, Dota 2 has carries across all types, including ability carries and tanky carries, and the same goes for most other MOBAs.

I also agree further down that itemization needs some serious changes, as the sheer difference in raw stats between classes is a major reason why some champions cannot carry even if their kit innately predisposes them to a strong late game. On a surface level, stats from items are now pretty excessive for how quickly matches progress now, and are a major reason why the game feels so snowbally, so toning them down across the board and adjusting the stats of late-game objectives could help make combat feel less one-sided. On a more fundamental level, items as a system no longer truly accomplish their original purpose, i.e. that of offering varied choices and different playstyles for every champion, with stat-binding achieving the exact opposite effect, and so it raises the question as to how it should fundamentally change in order to give champions the customization and adaptability players want from them.

Let's not exaggerate. Mages have {{item:3165}} to build as a first item and don't need as many stats to get going. ADCs need a BF and a zeal item to become even slightly relevant. There's a reason mid laners tend to dominate damage statistics. They come online earlier and are more useful earlier. If ADCs are somehow strong early, then why don't we see more of them mid? Literally only Corki is played in solo-q as a midlaner, and his pickrate is low too.

That aside, the meta, I believe, is tilted in ADCs favor late game, due to the nature of front to back teamfighting in a tank + enchanter meta. That is a combination of 3 classes of champions, though, which makes it more of a general meta problem than ADC problem. If you are a better ADC but the enemy team has a better protection comp, your skill advantage means nothing.

They could nerf enchanters and buff assassins but then again, everyone will start complaining about assassins being "broken".

The only reason adcs feel like they have no counterplay is because of supports like Janna Lulu soraka etc that don't even give assassins/mages a chance to kill them.

Well, plus the fact that every class update is designed with marksmen in mind, all while marksmen skate by abusing what the update is supposed to be fixing for that specific class (assassins bursting too reliably and in a short window, mages never worrying about resources, drain tanks, etc).
ADCs should need, at *minimum*, IE, a Zeal Item, and one more AD item on top of that before they become the least bit relevant.

That's at least 9000 worth of gold, though, which is frankly too much as mages can become relevant with less than half of that. Especially with lanes ending as early as they are, ADCs would once again have the problem of the game being 100% decided by their teammates. 

And honestly, ADCs still are kinda screwed by the meta in terms of individual play. Because you can be better than the enemy ADC, but if they have a peeling support with censer and a tank jungler, and you don't, there's nothing you can do. So I think giving them a window to have some individual impact before the game comes down to teamcomp.

There may be a few possible solutions. If ADC itemization is nerfed, then that should be accompanied with changes that slow down the pace of the game. Ardent censer definitely needs a nerf, and jungle needs to be looked at as a role as well.
The usefulness of mages is decided by how well they can support the ADC. That's the problem.

As far as lifesteal, grevious wounds helps. Also, try assassin. Deleting an adc is possible before they outright melt you (which is their job late game). If that doesn't work, try engage champs, then back off when they target you and let your assassins/burst mages wreck them while they target you.
